# **Market for Pollution: Price vs. Quantity Approaches** {background-color="#1c4982"}

## ‚ùì Why Not Just Regulate?

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    ‚ÄúIf the government knows the **socially optimal level of pollution**, why not just **mandate** it directly?‚Äù
  </blockquote>
</div>

- **Regulation (quantity control)** has been the **traditional approach**, since it seems straightforward:
  - 1970s: U.S. **limited SO‚ÇÇ emissions** rather than taxing them.  
  - 1987: Global **ban on CFCs** to protect the ozone layer instead of taxing them.

- For **climate change**, however, economists highlight **market-based policies** that use prices or permits to guide behavior.
  - **Carbon taxes** (price-based) and **cap-and-trade** (quantity-based) are the two main policy instruments for reducing GHG emissions.

- Let's examine **when** each‚Äî**price** or **quantity**‚Äîis more effective for achieving climate goals.

## üåç Climate Policy Instruments: The Core Idea

<div style="display:block; margin:5px;"></div>

<div style="font-size:1.9rem; max-width:1000px; margin:0.5rem auto;">

| **Approach** | **Instrument** | **Mechanism** | **Examples** |
|---|---|---|---|
| <span class="fragment">**Price-based**</span> | <span class="fragment">**Carbon Tax**</span> | <span class="fragment">Sets a **price per ton of CO‚ÇÇ**; firms reduce emissions until <u>*MC = tax*</u>.</span> | <span class="fragment">Sweden CO‚ÇÇ tax; Canada‚Äôs national carbon pricing system</span> |
| <span class="fragment">**Quantity-based (with flexibility)**</span> | <span class="fragment">**Cap-and-Trade**</span> | <span class="fragment">Sets a **cap on total emissions**; firms trade emission permits until<br><u>*permit price = MC*</u>.</span> | <span class="fragment">European Union Emissions Trading System (EU ETS); California‚Äôs Cap-and-Trade Program</span> |

</div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:2rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  Goal: **Achieve climate targets at the lowest total social cost.**
</div>




## üîÑ From Goods to Pollution Reduction

To compare **price** and **quantity** approaches effectively, we must shift focus:

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:2rem;">
  <blockquote>
    From the **market for a product** (like automobile)  
    ‚Üí to the **market for pollution reduction** (like CO‚ÇÇ) itself.
  </blockquote>
</div>


- In basic models, the only way to cut pollution was to **reduce output**.  
- In reality, firms can also **adopt cleaner technologies**:
  - Power plants install **CCUS** to capture CO‚ÇÇ.  
  - Cars use **catalytic converters** to reduce NO‚Çì emissions.

<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:2rem; margin-top:1.2rem;">
üëâ  This shift helps us analyze **abatement decisions directly** ‚Äî how firms respond to
  <strong>taxes (prices)</strong> or <strong>caps (quantities)</strong> when multiple reduction options exist.
</div>

<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

- Government imposes a **Pigouvian tax (œÑ)** on each unit of pollution equal to its **marginal damage (MD)** ‚Äî for example, \$100 per ton of CO‚ÇÇ.

# **Heterogeneous Plants** {background-color="#1c4982"}


## üè≠ Heterogeneous Plants
<div style="display:block; margin:-20px;"></div>

We now consider a case with **two plants** that have **different marginal abatement costs (MC)** ‚Äî a more realistic setting for policy design.

<div style="display:block; margin:10px;"></div>

| **Plant** | **MC** | **Efficient Reduction (example)** |
|---|---:|---:|
| A (newer tech) | Lower | 150 |
| B (older tech) | Higher | 50 |

<div style="display:block; margin:10px;"></div>

- In reality, firms differ in **technology, age, and fuel mix**, leading to **unequal costs** of pollution reduction.  
<!-- - An **efficient policy** must account for these differences ‚Äî the **same total reduction** can be achieved **at lower total cost** if **low-cost firms reduce more** and **high-cost firms reduce less**.   -->
- This setup helps us compare how **quantity regulation (like command-and-control)** and **price-based policies (like a carbon tax & cap-and-trade)** perform under realistic conditions.

<div style="display:block; margin:-25px;"></div>

:::callout-note
- **Command-and-control regulation**: Government **mandates specific pollution reductions** or **sets technology standards** that firms must **follow directly** to control emissions.
:::

<!-- <div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.6rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1rem;"> -->
<!--   ‚öôÔ∏è Real-world efficiency requires **equalizing marginal costs**, not equal reductions. -->
<!-- </div> -->


<!-- - **Equal command-and-control cuts** (100 each) ‚Üí **inefficient**. -->
<!-- - **Tax (œÑ = MD)** or **tradable permits** ‚Üí *A reduces more, B less*, total reduction unchanged, **costs minimized**.   -->

## üè≠ Heterogeneous Plants: Quantity with Flexibility

- The government sets a **total emissions cap** (e.g., 200 permits) and lets firms **trade** them.   
  - Each permit allows **one unit of pollution**. <span class="fragment">(**Coase Theorem!**)</span>

- **A firm will:**
  - **Abate** if its **MC** is **less than the permit price** ‚Üí cheaper to clean than to buy.  
  - **Buy permits** if its **MC** is **greater than the permit price** ‚Üí cheaper to pollute than to clean.  
  - Trading continues until **no further mutually beneficial trades exist** ‚Äî just like in a *Coase bargain*.  

<div style="display:block; margin:-35px;"></div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1rem; margin-bottom:1rem; color:#0072B2;">

**MC<sub>A</sub>(Q<sub>A</sub>) = MC<sub>B</sub>(Q<sub>B</sub>) = Permit Price**. 

</div>

<div style="display:block; margin:-35px;"></div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1rem; margin-bottom:1rem; color:#0072B2;">

<span class="fragment">(Because the cap is the socially optimal level,)</span> **Permit Price = MD**.$\qquad\qquad\quad\;$

</div>
<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>


- <u>The result</u>: the **pollution target is met** at the **lowest total cost**.
  <!-- as all firms face the **same marginal cost of abatement**. -->

## üè≠ Heterogeneous Plants: Summary

<div style="font-size:1.4rem; max-width:1000px; margin:0.5rem auto;">

| **Policy Type** | **What Is Set (Policy Lever)** | **Who Decides Reduction?** | **Efficiency** | 
|---|---|---|---|
| **Command-and-control** | <span class="fragment">Set **reduction amount** (e.g., 100 each)</span> | <span class="fragment">**Government mandates** cuts</span> | <span class="fragment">‚ùå *Inefficient* if abatement costs differ</span> | 
| **Price Regulation (Tax)** | <span class="fragment">Set **price per unit (œÑ)**</span> | <span class="fragment">**Firms choose** abatement</span> | <span class="fragment">‚úÖ *Efficient* ‚Äî firms reduce until **MC = œÑ**</span> | 
| **Cap-and-Trade** | <span class="fragment">Set **total emissions cap**</span> | <span class="fragment">**Firms trade permits**</span> | <span class="fragment">‚úÖ *Efficient* ‚Äî firms trade until **MC‚Çê = MC·µ¶ = permit price**</span> | 


</div>

<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>


- ‚öñÔ∏è **Command-and-control** regulations are **simple but often inefficient**.  
- üí° **Market-based instruments** ‚Äî such as **carbon taxes** and **cap-and-trade** ‚Äî let firms decide **how much to abate** based on their own costs.  
- This flexibility ensures the <span style="color:#009E73; font-weight:bold;">Cost-Effectiveness (Equimarginal) Principle</span> holds: <span class="fragment">**MCs** become **equalized across firms**</span><span class="fragment">, leading to an **efficient allocation of abatement**.</span>
- ‚úÖ <u>Result</u>: the **climate target is achieved at the lowest total social cost**.

# **Uncertainty about Costs of Reduction** {background-color="#1c4982"}

## üå´Ô∏è Uncertainty about Costs of Reduction

- In reality, **marginal abatement costs (MC)** are **uncertain** ‚Äî policymakers may not know the exact cost of cutting pollution.  
  - They can estimate the overall **MC curve**, but cannot know its exact **slope or position** when designing policy.
- This uncertainty means the **actual abatement level** may differ from what policymakers intended ‚Äî the **socially optimal level**.
- The **welfare loss from being wrong** depends on how **sensitive marginal damages (MD)** are to changes in emissions.  
- Under uncertainty, the **preferred policy instrument** ‚Äî **price (tax)** or **quantity (cap)** ‚Äî depends on the **slope of the MD curve**:
  - If **MD is steep**, errors in abatement lead to **large welfare losses**. 
  - If **MD is flat**, errors in abatement cause **only minor welfare impacts**.

## üåç Climate Change and Policy Design
### Carbon Tax vs. Cap-and-Trade

- The **benefits** of emissions reductions are linked to the **stock of greenhouse gases** in the atmosphere.  
  - What matters for climate damage is the **total accumulated CO‚ÇÇ**, not short-term fluctuations.

- The **costs** of emissions reductions are tied to the **flow of emissions** ‚Äî  
  how much we cut **this year** or **in the near term**.  

<div style="display:block; margin:-30px;"></div>

<div class="fragment" style="text-align:center; font-size:2rem; color:#0072B2; margin-top:1rem;">

üí° The **marginal benefits** of emission reductions are **insensitive** to the current level of abatement  
‚Üí small short-run emission changes have little effect on total warming.

</div>

- Under **uncertainty about abatement costs**, a **carbon tax** is preferred to **cap-and-trade** for **stock pollutants** like CO‚ÇÇ <span class="fragment">, because **emission errors are low-cost**, while **price errors can be large**.</span>




# üåç Carbon Pricing in Practice: Carbon Tax vs. Cap-and-Trade  {background-color="#1c4982"}


## ‚öñÔ∏è Price vs. Quantity: The Policy Trade-off

- Policymakers face a fundamental trade-off between:
  - Achieving a **specific emissions target** with certainty, and  
  - Ensuring **stable and predictable costs** for firms and consumers.


:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### **Carbon Tax**
- Provides **price certainty** ‚Äî firms know exactly what a ton of CO‚ÇÇ costs.
- But **emissions outcomes** can fluctuate with energy demand and economic cycles.

:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
### **Cap-and-Trade**
- Provides **environmental certainty** ‚Äî a fixed cap on total emissions.
- But **abatement costs** can vary widely depending on shocks and economic conditions.

:::
::::

## üìÑ Carbon Tax ‚Äî Big Advantages

- **Simple & Transparent**
  - Clear structure; easy to understand and implement.
  - Requires fewer new institutions and administrative layers.

<!-- - **Price Certainty** -->
<!--   - **Stable, predictable prices** support long-term planning for firms and households. -->

- **Adapts to Technological Change**
  - If abatement costs fall or cleaner technologies become cheaper, **a carbon tax automatically delivers greater emissions reductions** because firms reduce more wherever it's economically efficient.
  - Under **cap-and-trade**, lower abatement costs simply **drive down permit prices**.   
    - Total emissions remain fixed at the cap, and some firms may even emit more as compliance becomes cheaper.

## üéØ Why Cap-and-Trade Is More Popular in Practice
<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>
<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    _‚ÄúIt has become too politically divisive and a distraction from the important issues we are tackling.‚Äù_ Government of British Colombia, ‚ÄúB.C. Eliminates Carbon Tax,‚Äù (March 31, 2025)
  </blockquote>
</div>

- Even though economists often prefer **carbon taxes** (price stability + administrative simplicity), **cap-and-trade** is more politically feasible:
  - It avoids the politically sensitive term **‚Äútax,‚Äù** reducing public resistance.
    - Introducing a new tax is often **politically infeasible**, even when it is economically efficient.
  - It enables governments to **grant free permits** in the early stages, helping secure industry buy-in.
  - It is presented as a **flexible, market-driven mechanism**, which appeals to policymakers and firms.
  
  <!-- - It provides **clear, measurable emissions targets**, allowing politicians and environmental groups to easily track and communicate progress. -->
